Riding in heavy rain is something that almost
all of us have got to do at some point. But

6.text:
there are a few quick tips you can use to
make the whole experience a lot less unpleasant.

11.text:
Most of this starts before you even get on
your bike. Preparation is the key - for your

15.text:
clothing, your bike and also where you ride.
Now I think it's almost impossible to stay

20.text:
completely dry when riding in the rain, but
there a are a few key pieces that I use every

26.text:
time I go out in the wet, whether it's warm
rain or cold rain. First of all, a jacket.

30.text:
You have to weigh up the pros and cons of
whether the sweat buildup inside a jacket

35.text:
is actually worth it from staying dry from
the outside. In a lot of situations, a soft-shell

40.text:
might be better. This is less water-resistant,
but a lot more breathable. For me personally,

45.text:
I think that it is, and I think that one look
at the pro peloton on wet days also suggests

49.text: that this is the case as well.

51.text:
Secondly, waterproof overshoes. You can get
really thin ones, so you don't always have to

55.text:
use chunky neoprene ones all the time. But
my pro tip is to get thin waterproof overshoes

60.text:
and then also thin neoprene ones as well so
you can layer these almost as if you would

64.text: on any other part of your body.

66.text:
Thirdly: the roadie cap. In this age of helmets,
it only really comes into its own on wet days

72.text:
where it serves a dual role. Firstly keeping
some of the water out of your eyes and then

77.text:
also providing a little extra insulation for
your head, keeping you warm.

81.text:
Finally, with wet weather often comes poor
visibility. So although black cycling kit

86.text:
is pretty trendy, so too is fluoro kit nowadays,
so it's worth really thinking about this so

91.text:
that you really stand out when you're riding
your bike.

93.text:
Your clothing's sorted, what about your bike?
The first thing to contend with with wet weather

99.text:
is the reduced grip on the roads. To combat
this you can reduce your tyre pressures by

104.text:
10-20psi, which increases the contact patch
of the tyre and should give you more grip.

108.text:
You also need to think about the lubricant
that you're going to put on your chain. A

112.text:
thick, wet weather lubricant is much more
resistant to moisture and is going to last

118.text:
longer. There's nothing worse than a dry chain after a heavy
downpour, it's potentially one of the most

125.text:
If you're going to be riding in wet weather
a lot, it's actually worth considering buying

129.text:
some mudguards. Our favourites are the Crud
Roadracer Mk2s. They can fit on just about

135.text:
any bike, so you don't need a specific frame
with extra bosses. They actually don't look

139.text:
that bad either, but most of all they give
you amazing protection from wet weather. If

145.text:
you've never tried a set of mudguards before,
I suggest you do.

148.text:
You can actually help yourself a great deal
by thinking more about where you ride. As

152.text:
one of the biggest problems with wet weather
is getting cold, I tend to avoid big climbs

156.text:
because big climbs also mean big descents. At this
point, where you're not really producing much

161.text:
effort, but the windchill is higher, you can
really freeze. Some of my darkest moments

166.text:
on road bikes have come in precisely these
situations.

169.text:
If time on the bike is important to you, for
example if you're training for something specific

173.text:
and you need to do a certain amount of hours,
I've often found that doing loops closer to

177.text:
home really helps me to stay out on
the bike longer in foul conditions. I don't know

181.text:
quite why this is, but knowing that I can
get home quickly if the weather turns bad

185.text: often makes me stay out and hold out for longer.

190.text:
The final bit of preparation is chamois cream.
Most of us probably don't need to use this

193.text:
much, if at all, but on wet days when you're
going to be spending a long time in the saddle,

197.text:
it's worth considering. This is because your
skin gets much more susceptible to chafing

202.text:
when it's wet, so spending a long time on
the bike could lead to some pretty painful

206.text:
experiences. The best thing to do is put it
on before you set off before any kind of chafing

211.text:
Finally, now we're out on our bikes, bear
in mind that wet bikes and wet roads make

216.text:
braking and cornering more hazardous. This
is partly due to less grip and partly due

220.text:
to the inefficiencies of wet rim brakes. We've
covered both of these topics at length in

225.text:
their own videos, so you can click on these
to see all our pro tips.
